Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: Your I04iend calls you in the middle of the night, crying, because they just received some devastating family news.
Situation2: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Story: It was just after midnight when my phone buzzed, jolting me awake in the lifeguard’s break room. My best friend’s name flashed on the screen. I answered, and immediately heard her sobbing—her voice cracked as she told me her dad had been rushed to the hospital. She needed me to listen, to be there, to help her hold it together. I pressed the phone to my ear, murmuring comfort, trying to focus on her words. But through the glass, I caught sight of a group of teenagers at the pool, laughing and edging dangerously close to the deep end, ignoring the bold red “NO DIVING” signs. My supervisor had drilled it into us: safety first, always intervene. My friend’s pain pulled at me, but so did my duty to keep those kids safe. My heart pounded as I stood there, torn between the desperate voice in my ear and the reckless laughter outside, knowing I couldn’t be in both places at once.
